content: The "Industrial Hemp Banking Act" is the short title of the Act. It aims to ensure secure and fair enforcement of banking laws. The "Industrial Hemp Banking Act" prohibits Federal banking regulators from terminating deposit insurance for institutions serving hemp businesses or discouraging financial services to them. The "Industrial Hemp Banking Act" prohibits depository institutions from discriminating against account holders who are involved in industrial hemp legitimate businesses. The "Industrial Hemp Banking Act" prohibits adverse actions on loans made to owners or operators of industrial hemp legitimate businesses or real estate leased to such businesses. The "Industrial Hemp Banking Act" protects depository institutions providing financial services to industrial hemp businesses from liability under Federal law for following state regulations and investing income from these services. The "Industrial Hemp Banking Act" ensures that depository institutions offering financial services to industrial hemp businesses are not at risk of forfeiture under Federal law. It does not mandate these institutions to provide financial services to such businesses. Additionally, there are specific requirements for filing suspicious activity reports related to industrial hemp legitimate businesses. The Industrial Hemp Banking Act requires depository institutions to comply with guidance from the Financial Crimes Enforcement Network when providing financial services to industrial hemp legitimate businesses. The Act aims to ensure that these businesses can access financial services without hindrance in states that permit them. The term "Federal banking regulator" refers to various federal agencies overseeing banking and financial services, including the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and the National Credit Union Administration. The term "financial service" refers to a financial product or service defined in the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act. An "industrial hemp legitimate business" includes institutions of higher education or State departments of agriculture conducting research on industrial hemp. The term "State" refers to each of the several states where institutions of higher education or State departments of agriculture conduct research on industrial hemp. This includes third parties involved in the production, manufacturing, sale, purchase, or transportation of industrial hemp, as well as individuals engaged in commerce with exempted industrial hemp products. The term "State" includes several states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, and any U.S. territory or possession. The terms "agricultural pilot program", "industrial hemp", and "State department of agriculture" are defined under the Agricultural Act of 2014.
